div.p: In many countries mobile phones have become a normal part of daily life for almost everyone, from professionals, such as doctors and lawyers, to young children. Some people, however, would like like liked to see ownership restricted because of the possible risks these phones pose to our health and the negative impact they are already having on society. But should such restrictions be imposed?

There are some persuasive arguments in favour of restricting ownership. Firstly, radio wave emissions from mobile phones are known known have known to affect brain activity and some scientists are worried about the effects this may have on the health of children who use such phones. It is claimed I claim It claims that fewer people would be exposed exposed expose to these risks if restrictions were introduced have been intorduced are introduced . Furthermore, it is generally sometimes often agreed that such measures would reduce reduced be reduced the number of traffic accidents caused by people talking on their mobile phones. There is also the social impact to consider. It is now common for a concert, a theatrical performance or even a quiet meal in a restaurant to be disrupted by an inconsiderate mobile phone user. It is sometimes said We sometimes say They sometimes say that none of this would be the case if the government restricted will restrict restricts ownership to professional use only.

On the other hand, there are strong arguments against such measures. Firstly, it is widely hightly broadly believed that mobile phones are indispensable in the case of accidents, or when other difficult situations arise, and that everyone should have the right to the protection they offer. Secondly, it is argued that if phone companies did will do do more to raise public awareness of the risks posed by radio wave emissions, people would only make short calls from their phones and these risks would then be reduced. Finally, it is often always never pointed out that there will always be a minority of inconsiderate people and that restrictions on ownership would unfairly penalise have penalised penalised the majority of considerate users.

To sum up, I believe it is believed I am believed that some restrictions on ownership to protect young people's health would probably be were probably would not be a good thing. However, adults should have the right to use mobile phones if they wish, for both personal and professional purposes.
